#Text=South African apartheid assassin Eugene de Kock granted parole
#Text=Saturday , January 31 , 2015
#Text=South African Justice Minister Michael Masutha yesterday announced he is granting parole to Eugene de Kock , an apartheid -era assassin who has spent twenty years in prison .
#Text=A photo from the Truth and Reconciliation Commission headquarters shows de Kock with film director Jann Turner .
#Text=Image : George Hallett .
#Text=After South Africa 's first democratic elections in 1994
#Text=de Kock was arrested and subsequently detailed his actions to the nation 's Truth and Reconciliation Commission ( TRC ) .
#Text=As head of a police ' counter-insurgency ' unit de Kock took responsibility for murdering and torturing dissidents opposed to white-only rule .
#Text=His methods included bombings , shootings , and stabbings and he operated internationally and at home .
#Text=His revelations earned him the nickname " Prime Evil " .
#Text=The TRC granted de Kock immunity for most crimes in exchange for his testimony .
#Text=He was charged with remaining offences , not covered due to limits in TRC power , and in 1996 jailed for life for six murders .
#Text=Additional convictions include kidnap and attempted murder .
#Text=He received an additional 212-year term for those crimes .
#Text=The TRC could only grant immunity where the offence was a human rights violation and the offender gave a full confession .
#Text=During his TRC testimony de Kock accused police commanders of ordering murders including those of African National Council ( ANC ) members .
#Text=In a 2007 prison interview he said FW de Klerk , the last white President , had hands " soaked in blood " .
#Text=De Klerk denies de Kock 's allegations he ordered individual murders .
#Text=It 's mixed feelings , which is something we 've gotten used to as South Africans — Eddie Makue
#Text=In the early nineties
#Text=de Kock teamed up with anti-ANC party Inkatha to arrange violence within black communities .
#Text=Internal conflict killed 12,000 in the wake of future President Nelson Mandela 's release .
#Text=Mandela wrote of fearing " a hidden hand behind the violence[ ... ] attempting to disrupt the negotiations " , by orchestrating the clashes in Natal and Transvaal .
#Text=He was referring to upcoming elections and a transfer of power away from white rule and apartheid .
#Text=Masutha said de Kock was being released " in the interest of reconciliation and nation building " .
#Text=The date , location , and terms are to remain secret .
#Text=Reaction from his victims is varied .
#Text=Murder victim Glenack Mama 's widow Sandra welcomed the release .

#Text=She said to a BBC reporter " I think it will actually close a chapter in our history because we 've come a long way and I think his release will just once again help with the reconciliation process because there 's still a lot of things that we need to do as a country " .
#Text=She said " He got the instructions from the top and they [ more senior officials ] got away with it[ ... ]

#Text=Eddie Makue said to The Associated Press the release stirred up  mixed feelings , which is something we 've gotten used to as South Africans " .

column1: #Text=He was a South African Council of Churches employee in 1988 when de Kock bombed their headquarters .
#Text=Jane Quin said she was " terribly disappointed " and he should never be released .
#Text=Her sister Jacqui Quin was murdered in Lesotho in 1985 by de Kock .
#Text=TRC chairman
#Text=Archbishop Desmond Tutu said " I pray that those whom he hurt , those from whom he took loved ones , will find the power within them to forgive him . "
#Text=He said the release would not be universally welcome but is nonetheless " to our collective credit , as people and as a nation . "
#Text=Tutu called it " an indictment on our government " that apartheid officials who did not co-operate with the TRC had evaded prosecution .

column1: #Text=Whilst in prison de Kock has assisted the recovery of his missing victims ' remains .
#Text=Remorse and his help to the Missing Persons Task Team were cited by Masutha as reasons to release him , which was initially decided against last July .
#Text=" [ H]is key role has been to introduce us to other former security police who can assist with finding others , " said Task Team leader Madeleine Fullard .
#Text=Fullard said de Kock had also directly assisted in retrieving two bodies .
#Text=" He certainly feels lives were wasted for no reason " , she added , describing a meeting with him at one ANC victim 's grave .
#Text=" He seemed to be quite stressed .

column3:
_	_	_	_
